JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Elisabet Fura;Ineta Ziemele;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP and NORP citizen , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE . The second and third applicants are his children , PERSON , born in DATE , and PERSON , born in DATE . They currently live in GPE with PERSON , their mother .

CARDINAL . The first applicant and PERSON got married in DATE in GPE . The CARDINAL had already lived together as a couple in GPE for DATE before the wedding . In DATE and DATE respectively , their CARDINAL children , PERSON and PERSON , were born in GPE . Their last place of residence in GPE was PERSON .

CARDINAL . In DATE , as explained by the applicant , the couple , who had joint custody of the children , agreed that the mother and the CARDINAL children would visit the mother 's family in GPE for DATE . On DATE , the mother and the children left for GPE ; according to their roundtrip airline tickets , they were scheduled to be back on DATE .
However , they never returned to GPE ; on DATE , PERSON 's mother informed the first applicant that PERSON and the children would remain in GPE .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , the first applicant filed for the return of his children , under LAW ( proceedings described under no . CARDINAL below ) , while PERSON filed for divorce and custody of the children with the NORP courts ( proceedings described under no . CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant filed a request for the return of his children under LAW DATE on ORG ( “ LAW ) . The request was submitted through ORG to ORG ( “ the Ministry ” ) . The first applicant claimed that his wife was wrongfully retaining their children in GPE , without his consent .
On DATE the Ministry , acting as ORG for the purpose of LAW , instituted proceedings on behalf of the first applicant before ORG of FAC .

CARDINAL . On the basis of the evidence adduced in the case , which included a “ psychological evaluation of the children ” , ORG found on DATE that the retention of the children in GPE was illegal under LAW , as at the time of the retention the father had lawful custody rights . It also held that the allegations of PERSON according to which the first applicant had agreed that the children should remain in GPE as his financial situation in GPE was precarious , confirmed by the witness M .- A. T. , who stated that neither the applicant , nor PERSON had a job in GPE , were however unsubstantiated , as the first applicant had proved that he had made attempts to rent a house for the family , had enrolled the children in a local kindergarten and was regularly in contact with the children by phone .

The defence raised by ORG under LAW b ) of LAW was also dismissed by the court ; it considered that the “ state of insecurity ” invoked and the “ general threat of terrorist attacks ” arising in GPE had not proved to be an obstacle to the family living in GPE for DATE prior to the children 's removal , and could not be regarded as having developed to a dangerous degree at that time . The court ordered that the children be returned to their habitual residence in GPE DATE after the judgment became final .

CARDINAL . A.R. filed an appeal against this decision , which was allowed by ORG in a final judgment of DATE . Out of the panel of CARDINAL judges , Judge PERSON gave a dissenting opinion , favouring the reasoning of the first - instance court .

The majority 's decision was based on CARDINAL conclusions : firstly , that LAW was not applicable to the case , in so far as the children , NORP citizens , had left GPE and remained in GPE upon the agreement of the parents ; secondly , that in any event , the exception provided for by LAW b ) of the ORG was substantiated , as it had been proved that , if returned to GPE , the children would risk exposure to physical or psychological harm .

CARDINAL . The appellate court thus found that the children had left GPE and remained in GPE with the consent of their father , due to the worsening of his financial situation . The agreement between the parents was for the children to stay in GPE until the first applicant 's financial situation improved –in that respect , even the fact that they had bought roundtrip tickets , which were cheaper than CARDINAL - way tickets , only underlined the financial difficulties the family was undergoing ; however , as time passed , the evidence showed that this situation had kept worsening , since the first applicant had sold the house where they had lived as a family , after the departure of PERSON with the children , and gone to live with his mother . Also , the first applicant had not produced any evidence to support his claim that he had sent money to his children .

The court further held that the first applicant had not proved that he had maintained contact with his children ; in the file there was only evidence of CARDINAL visit paid by the first applicant to his children , on DATE ; the phone calls allegedly made by the first applicant to his children in GPE had been made from the house of the first applicant 's mother , which was interpreted as meaning that the conversations had been between the children and their paternal grandmother .
Hence , the agreement between the spouses regarding the children remaining in GPE proved to be real and such an agreement could by no means be regarded as breaching LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP Moreover , the evidence in the file showed that the CARDINAL children had integrated into the NORP community successfully – they had good results at kindergarten and positive psychological evaluations – arguments which supported a dismissal of the first applicant 's action . The court also held that “ the evaluation of the children carried out by ORG in the presence of a counsellor revealed that no assessment could be made of the possible effects of the separation of the father from his children , insofar as there was insufficient information with regard to the father - children relationship ” .

CARDINAL . The defence under LAW b ) of LAW , namely , that there was a grave risk of exposing the children to intolerable physical harm if returned to GPE , was also allowed . The court based their reasoning , inter alia , on “ the reports produced by ORG ” , which stated according to the court , that PERSON was located in a conflict area , where citizens feared for their safety . At the same time , the court based its reasoning on travel advice issued in DATE by ORG , in which warnings were allegedly made about “ potential conflicts which could arise between the NORP and the NORP ” , and “ signs of possible terrorist attacks in the area ” were referred to .
In a dissenting opinion to the judgment , Judge PERSON underlined that the above - mentioned documents “ did not actually refer specifically to PERSON , but to other regions of GPE ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant was never given a copy of the above - mentioned reports . In a certificate issued by ORG on DATE to the applicant it was mentioned that neither the ORG reports , nor the GPE ORG release were to be found in the domestic case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE , PERSON filed for divorce , custody of the children and maintenance before ORG of FAC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant ( defendant ) , represented by an appointed lawyer , presented his observations in reply to PERSON 's claims . He contended that the NORP courts did not have general jurisdiction in such proceedings , in so far as the marriage was registered in GPE , the defendant was an NORP and NORP citizen , the couple 's children were NORP citizens , and the last marital home had been in GPE .
He also lodged counterclaims asking the courts to either grant him full custody of the CARDINAL children , or to order their return to their habitual residence in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the court rejected the first applicant 's plea regarding the lack of jurisdiction , considering that “ the NORP courts did have full jurisdiction in such cases , pursuant to ORG ( ORG ) No . CARDINAL of DATE concerning jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and matters of parental responsibility ” .
CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE , the district court granted ORG a divorce on the grounds of exclusive fault by the first applicant .

Based on the conclusions of a social enquiry report on the children 's concrete situation , which held that they were well taken care of and benefited from a good standard of living , and taking into consideration their ages ( CARDINAL and DATE , at that time ) , the court awarded custody of the children to the mother . The court found that it was in their best interest to remain with their mother , her care and presence being a psychological factor which was absolutely essential for their intellectual , moral and physical development .

In the absence of any proof regarding the first applicant 's employment and/or income , the court referred to the national minimum wage scale and ordered him to pay DATE maintenance in the amount of CARDINAL PERSON in respect of each child , starting on DATE and until they reached the age of majority .
Neither the first applicant , nor PERSON have lodged any appeals against this judgment , which thus became final and enforceable .
